Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 12/01/2017
I have been at Southpoint Crossing a year and it's been a good experience so far. The staff are friendly, the grounds are well-kept, and it's located very conveniently. I especially like the fact that the Tobacco trail runs through the complex for us to use. Unfortunately, the ventilation within the homes is a bit weak - we can smell when our neighbors are smoking (not just cigs) indoors (we live on the top floor). I agree with another reviewer that it's a disappointment the pool isn't open longer through the year, especially as we experience warmer weather longer.

Report
Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/22/2017
I have been living at Southpoint Crossing for exactly a year and just gladly signed my renewal. Great and convenient location- Kroger right next door, the Southpoint Mall right down the street, so many different places to eat, Target is close too, downtown is an easy drive, my work even closer! The American Tobacco Trail is right next to my building! I love the space I have in my one bedroom, cute pretty view of the pond off my sweet balcony. The kitchen is HUGE for a one bedroom! You really get so much for what you are paying for! Maintenance is super quick and responsive, the office staff is extremely helpful, professional, responsive, and friendly. I feel very safe living here. It's common sense crime can happen ANYWHERE. The grounds are very taken care of and clean. Only wish that there was a valet trash service to get rid of trash instead of walking/driving it all the way to the dumpster. Lovely community! I highly recommend this community for all!

Report
Resident
2016 - 2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/28/2017
Overall this apartment complex was a great living spot. It is central to everything most folks need (groceries, Target, mall, UPS, etc.). The staff are friendly and responsive (for the most part - see below). Maintenance issues were addressed in a timely fashion. The grounds were kept clean and well-manicured. The community is quiet. Our only ongoing issue was with a neighbor, which of course the complex had little control over. However, we did not feel like the issue was addressed properly. We called the courtesy officer (which is an awesome perk the complex offers) about an issue and were ignored! This made us less inclined to call about the same issue as it continued so we ended up just dealing with the problem. One of the biggest factors for moving out was the way this neighbor impacted our living space. We wish something had been done. This was are biggest issue with the complex. Otherwise, I would recommend it for young professionals and/or couples looking for somewhere affordable.

Report
Resident
2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/28/2016
Location: Very convenient to I-40 and 54. You are directly behind Kroger and the Southpoint Crossing Shopping Center making it very convenient to walk. Parking: Parking is not assigned and completely open to guests. This always makes me a little wary but in this community it works. I have never had a problem finding a space regardless of late night arrival and it is nice to have guests and not worry about passes. Maintenance: I have had few maintenance issues since moving here but they were all handled competently and usually same day. They are also proactive about routine filter changes and preventative maintenance which I appreciated. Noise: Yes, I can hear the people above me walking around and vacuuming. However, this has been the case with every apartment I have ever lived in. Our apartment is one of the closest to Kroger and we do get some ambient noise from deliveries but are on the fountain side which drowns out most of it. In my opinion the benefits of the close proximity to Kroger outweigh this and I would imagine very few buildings can hear the noise. Grounds: This community is fairly spread out making it quite peaceful. Grounds are always maintained. Office Staff: My interaction with office staff has been fairly limited but always positive. I have found them responsive to maintenance requests and concerns. Overall: We have lived here one year and have been very happy here. If it were not for the fact that we were buying a house we would have renewed our lease.

Report
Resident
2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/08/2016
Southpoint crossing has been a great apartment community to live in. It is conveniently located next to Kroger, The American Tobacco Trail and a Fitness World (a wonderful local gym). It is a quiet and friendly community as I have found mostly professionals and families reside there. In addition to the grounds being maintained, the staff at Southpoint Crossing makes sure that the apartments are kept in clean and working condition. Living in a one bedroom apartment, I appreciated the functional layout of the apartment and the amount of storage space especially in the kitchen. In addition, I appreciated the well lit stair wells and parking lots at night and the double bolted doors. One recommendation is that if you are bringing a washer and dryer, make sure you get the measurements because I found it to be a tight fit in my floor plan. Overall, I have had a great experience at Southpoint Crossing and would highly recommend it.

Thanks for voting!
Report
Resident
2015 - 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 03/27/2016
I could almost say that I had no complaints about this apartment, but my experience with ending my lease was abysmal! We decided to end our lease because the complex was raising their rent at the end of the year to a level we were uncomfortable with paying. However, the complex was nice and the office people had been friendly, so I had no complaints at that time. However, when time came for my security deposit to be returned, I found out that not only had they kept my deposit, but were asking for an addition $80! They claimed that my two pets had irreparably damaged the carpet such that it needed to be replaced. I know for a fact that my cats had neither peed on nor scratched up that carpet in my one year there, so I asked for proof of the damage in the form of pictures. The office staff were consistently very slow in responding to this issue, often taking up to 8+ days to get back to me, and only when I would respond a second time, asking for a response. No pictures were provided, nor could they provide a detailed description of the damage or its location. At one point during the interaction, I went to the Better Business Bureau, since I was frustrated with the lack of response that the staff was giving me. It turns out they didn't feel compelled to respond to the BBB either. I also asked why, if my pets HAD damaged the carpet (again, I KNOW that they didn't), why could they not use the $400 in pet rent or the $400 pet deposit I had paid to cover the cost. Was that not the point of pet rent? It turns out that no, this apartment is very okay with charging you $800 for the sheer privilege of owning a pet on campus. Every other article on pet rent that I can find indicates that pet rent and pet deposits are generally used because landlords acknowledge the increased wear and tear that pets can cause, and use that rent to offset pet damage. Not so at Southpoint Crossing. Here you just pay a lot of money for the joy of having your animal friends live with you. Long story short, if you own a pet and are looking to live at Southpoint Crossing Apartment: (A) Take extensive pictures before and after your lease. Be ready for erroneous claims of pet damage, and be ready to prove that your pet did not damage the apartment. (B) Don't. Pick an apartment with a reasonable Pet Rent policy. (C) If all else fails, lie and say you don't own a pet. I would normally not advocate for such a breach of contract, but their behavior with handling this issue has lost them all of my respect.

Report
Resident
2015 - 2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/15/2016
The good - Maintenance requests have been taken care of quickly - I feel safe here - Close to Kroger's - The American Tobacco Trail runs along the property The bad - Maintenance repair quality is questionable. I had to have a new pad put at the base of the toilet because it was leaking. After the repair there was red gel coming out in the shower, toilet, and, sink for about 6 months. Needless to say I got used to washing my hands in the kitchen. - Upstairs neighbor has a dog that is left alone for extended periods which causes it to bark, whine, and try to claw its way out of the apartment. This usually lasts 30-90 minutes and happens on most days, up to 4 times. I complained about this 7-8 months ago and then again this weekend. They said it was the first complaint they have heard. Not surprising since I felt like they didn't take me seriously the first time I complained. - Sometimes the dumpster area is so cluttered with junk from tenants it makes it difficult to get to the recycling. Also, the dumpster can get to overflowing and residents drop the garbage next to it by the recycling. This has happened several times since I have been there. I consider this more of a resident problem. - I just got my rent + fee increase and it is $88.50 if I sign before the end of the month or $113.50, almost a 15% increase, if I wait until after March 1st. Personally, such an increase should be criminal but I heard this is common in the Raleigh-Durham metro and have seen 10%+ increases twice now. Once for each apartment I lived in. For a 1 bedroom non-upgraded apartment this is outrageous. I could get a $170K-$185K house with 20% down, mortgage, interest, insurance, and taxes for what they are asking me to pay after March 1st.

I moved in here when the previous owners were here and have been here about 2 years now. I haven't had any major issues and I feel like the front office staff always help me out if I do have any concerns. The maintenance guys are also very quick to respond. The only minor issue I have had was with loud neighbors above me and with a quick request to the front office, I haven't had any other problems. The neighborhood is very safe and quiet too. I have not had any safety concerns at all. The renewal process with these owners was also quite easy and they did not up my lease fees like they might at some places. I love the fact that I can walk to the Kroger, Walgreens and restaurants too. Also the ATT runs directly through the complex so now I can walk from my apartment to the mall and Target in less than a mile. I do have a dog and haven't had any issues with any other dog owners. Everyone picks up and all are quiet too. I would recommend this location to anyone looking to move to the Durham or RTP area. The entrance to I-40 couldn't be closer. They have various unit options and the pool and workout rooms are always clean and free to use. I would definitely move here again if I were trying to find a place in this area.

Resident
2012 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/12/2014
I've lived in this complex for almost 2 years and have really enjoyed my time here. The apartments are a very good size, and the layout of the apartment works very well. The location is also great; near two grocery stores and plenty of other shopping. The apartment complex is on the American Tobacco Trail as well, which is extremely convenient for anyone who enjoys walking, jogging, biking etc. Due to the ATT expanding across the I-40 freeway, there is now also convenient access to the Streets at Southpoint Mall (about a 15 minute walk). My only complaint is that there is only one area in the complex for dropping off trash. I often have to drive trash to the dumpster. I also would like to see commingeled recycling. Currently all recycled items must be separated. This makes it a bit more difficult to successfully recycle. I think more residents would participate in recycling if all recyclables could be thrown in together. As someone who takes recycling seriously, this is something I would like to see. I do not see the above mentioned issue as a fault or complaint, but rather an opportunity for this to be an even better place to live. I have really enjoyed my time here.

It should be fairly obvious they have hired somebody like 'reputation.com' to 'stack the deck' since there is a flurry of positive only, 'brochure talk' comments coming in. Previously, there was little posted. That they have ratings better than high end apartments in the area is also suspicious. I still bicycle through the property since the 'Tobacco Trail' ... jogging and bicycle...goes right through it. I lived there for several years in a 2 bedroom some years ago. Generally, parking and maintenance was good, construction was better for maintenance than for residents (small rooms, low ceilings but good cabinets), noise a problem (they are right behind a shopping plaza and some residents could be loud) and safety variable...but that could have changed since at one time they had a roaming guard at night and might still. Office staff is responsive but the group's goals are for full occupancy rather than either satisfaction or paradoxically, cash flow is not the major goal(go figure?!?).

2011 - 2014 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/06/2014
My experience has been generally positive. Great location (walking distance to shopping), direct access to the American Tobacco Trail, pretty good neighbors (though so far that'd be pure luck I suppose), and rent, though it has risen over the two and a half years of my stay, has only risen about $80 since moving in. Yes, the geese can be annoying and their feces is frequently found around but it hasn't been a major issue. I happen to like the pond (I'll never call the thing a lake) and my apartment faces it. The white noise of the twin fountains in the pond help buffer noise, I think. I generally feel safe, but I do find the gates to have issues from time to time. Office staff is indeed great. I enjoy chatting when I stop by for a package. Maintenance issues are generally taken care of in a timely manner. I have had bedbugs (last summer) but was able to eradicate them (supposedly they were carpet beetles). My blinds are hanging on, barely, and I've had issues with the sliding doors to the laundry "nook" but the issues I have experienced as of this review (5/6/14) have been reasonable for apartment living. I'd recommend this place!

Resident
2013 - 2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 03/13/2014
I have lived here for just under a year now. I moved in back in August as a graduate student. When I met the workers in the office, I thought they were friendly enough and seemed genuinely interested in helping me get moved into my apartment. Honestly, for the most part, things have been fine. However, I would not live here if I had the opportunity to make the choice again for a few reasons. Rent - I am the type of person who wants to where every one of my dollars and coins is going. There have been a couple of instances where I was told to pay a certain amount and then told that I owed more later. Upon further investigation, it seemed like the workers did not even know what was going on. I received a bill from the water company (which typically contains rent, trash, sewage and water) which was $766. Then, when I went to pay my rent online, I was told to pay $769. I know it's only $3, but there is a business principal that's clearly being violated. Bugs - When I first moved in, this was more of a problem. I've had plenty of spiders, plenty of centipedes, a stink bug, and a roach since I moved in. Thankfully, I'm not too scared of insects, so I put them outside. I have sprayed my windows and doorways with bug spray and sprinkled cayenne pepper to keep them away. This has been successful for the most part. This spring and coming summer will be interesting though. Mold - There is mold growing beside my bedroom window. I have not contacted the office about this yet, but it's coming soon. I will update when I know more. Bathroom mirror - Oddly enough, when I moved in, my bathroom mirror had black spots ALL over it. I don't know how a maintenance or cleaning worker could see that and not take it down for a new resident, but I contacted the office when I moved in. They said the maintenance manager would take a look and determine whether I needed a new one. He replaced it. Office - Overall, I love the people in the leasing office! The two ladies, Dawn and Jenna, are very friendly and quick to help. However, I have walked into the office to pick up a package or ask a question and been required to wait for someone to acknowledge me when no other resident or prospective resident was in the office. I'm not sure if they were on breaks or what, but having worked in customer service, I know this is not the way to handle customers. Miscellaneous Issues - I have had other small miscellaneous issues that bother me. I understand that noise is a part of apartment living, but you can literally hear EVERY thing that your neighbor does. From TVs to music to walking around... it's very noisy. Dog and geese feces on the sidewalk. This apartment is home to a beautiful "lake" and very active geese. There are also designated dog "parks" throughout the complex, so it's a bit annoying to carry groceries and have to watch every little step you take to avoid stepping in the feces from those animals. There has to be a more effective way to handle this issue. One reason I chose this apartment community was due to its being gated. In a city like Durham, a gated community is almost a must. However, the gates are open at least 40% of the time. What's the point? One or two of these complaints would not be enough to make me want to leave, but with all of them compiled in less than a year, I'm really to go! I highly doubt that I'll renew my lease unless something drastic occurs in the next four months. There are some positives, which include the size of the apartment, adequate parking, and friendly staff.

Verified Manager04/23/2014

Hello Anonymous, thank you for your posting. I am sorry for the complication with the rent and utility billing. In order to provide better service to our residents we did recently switch utility billing companies. While we did incur a few complications with the invoices that were mailed out during this transition period, I can assure you no residents were over charged for rent and other services. If you would like to contact me directly I would be happy to go over the details of your account with you. Fortunately for us our community is located in an area where we experience warm temperatures 8 out of the 12 months of the year. This in turn allows us to open our windows and enjoy the sunshine and warm air. Unfortunately areas with warmer climates do tend to experience insects more often than those areas of a cooler climate. For this reason we provide our residents with weekly pest control service. If our residents are experiencing insects in their apartments they can notify management and have their apartment treated. I would like to make a correction to one misunderstanding. The mold around the window is actually not mold at all but mildew caused by the natural formation of condensation on the windows. This formation of mildew can easily be prevented by a regularly cleaning of the windows and by wiping down the windows when condensation is noticed. Over the winter months we did experience a few malfunctions with the access gates that required new parts be ordered. In order the lessen the inconvenience to our residents during these times of malfunction the gates are left open. I am very pleased that our office and maintenance staff have been able leave a good impression on you and again I encourage you to contact me at (919)544-6995 or pm.southpointcrossing@riverstoneres.com and make an appointment so that we discuss any other ways we may be able to improve our service to you. Elliott, Property Manager.

UPDATE 9/12-Just wanted to say that right after I wrote my last update that we got a severe infestation of ants. It is so frustrating dealing with those, as we had to about the same time last year. Scroll down to get a history of the issues- BUGS-As of this year, we have not had any ant infestations in the apartment. After talking to management about the huge ant problem last summer and the infestation in my car, I am optimistic that this summer is different. Things WE have done to prevent ant infestation-no garden on the balcony :( and parking my car in a different area of the complex. While we have seen some ants crawling around there have been so few that we could handle it ourselves. We also had the exterminator come directly to our apartment and spray which has probably helped. Notably, it is a different exterminator than the previous management used and I am happy with the outcome. Kudos to the managers for jumping on the problem when the ants started showing up and not after multiple infestations had already occurred. NOISE-Management definitely fixed the 4 am wake up call done by the guys fixing the pool. It still pisses me off that happened but it's not the complex's fault and it hasn't happened since. Also, there have not been any noisy residents at the pool past 10pm like there were earlier in the summer. The rest of the noise issues still exist but it's an apartment and not that big of a deal IMO. SMELLS-I brought this up to management so they would know if we left (WHICH WE ARE NOT NOW) one of the reasons why. It still sucks living next to these people with their strong ethnic food smell but the good news is they are moving out at the end of this month and I could NOT be happier. Seriously, if we wouldn't have found this out we would have had to move. I just couldn't take the disgusting smell anymore. Now I'm just praying the next neighbors to move in don't stink as well... WATER-THIS HAS BEEN FIXED! UNBELIEVABLE! It poured and flooded yesterday and not a puddle in sight on our property. I honestly can't believe it. Although it was long overdue I am glad this management GOT IT RIGHT. I wouldn't have commented on this unless there was a huge storm and yesterday just proved it to me. Very very good outcome. PLUMBING-This has NOT been addressed since I brought it up to management and it honestly never will. I had my dad (who builds houses) over to even give me an opinion and he said they would have to tear down the wall and fix the pipes (which I know they wouldn't do). It's still annoying but we can live with it. Grrrr. GATE/MAINTENANCE-no changes, but I also didn't bring these up because I thought it would be pointless. PAINT-My husband was thrilled that a few days after my complaints about the other issues management had the black railing painted and it looks amazing. This was something my husband brought up when we first moved here and nothing was done. It does look a lot nicer. It would look even better if the rest of the apartments could be power washed because there's tons of pollen everywhere. They did this at the last place we lived and it looked really nice. But yeah, we are happy about the coat of pain on the railings, it was much needed. POOL-I didn't know this but I guess the pool was busted. That's why I had my 4 am wake up call that one day that pushed me over the edge. Anyway, they got it fixed in 2 days and even had a pool party with all of the residents last Saturday (not that we care, but some people are into that thing). BOTTOM LINE-I have seen some serious improvements in less than a month's time. I am glad about this and it was apparently needed since almost everyone in our building has moved out. Hopefully it will continue to improve and the office's customer service will continue to be outstanding. Like I said below, they have been very approachable and professional through all of this. So even after these issues, we continue to live here because 1) it's a great location and 2) it's a good price for what you get. Rent prices have gone up everywhere and I am surprised to find out what some people pay in this area. I think for the most part, it is reasonable and we plan to stay until the end of our lease. ORIGINAL REVIEW: It's only fair that I admit we have not talked to the New Management about these issues yet. I am going to the office today about it and we'll see how it goes. My husband and I have lived here for 15 months and should have left after our first year but moving is a hassle and we are expecting so we thought it would be easier to stay. It's also a good location for us since my husband loves riding his bike on the trail to downtown Durham and I work in Raleigh. Rent is reasonable but definitely higher than last year and even resident's rates from 2 years ago. And now I am afraid we are going to have to move closer to my due date which is what we were trying to avoid but I can't take it anymore. My husband even agrees and he's not the hormonal one. We have both lived in under developed countries for over 3 years (in older and worse conditions) and have not experienced most ofthese issues, so don't think this is just a first-world problem. BUGS-First summer here we had a huge ant infestation. The company said it was due to the massive amounts of rain we had and that it was only our building. This was a huge issue to resolve and our neighbors had the same experience. Not only was the problem in our house but in our cars as well! I didn't plant a balcony garden this year in hopes to deter inviting anything over. I've already had a huge infestation in my car so I am parking a little farther away from our building and sprayed my car down with ant killer (love the fumes). We have seen some ants in the house exploring but nothing major yet. Also, when we first moved here I saw A roach on 2 occasions but none of those have returned . Which is good because I HATE roaches. I'd argue that it's not a cleanliness issue. It's a property problem. NOISE-When we first moved here I was working night shift so I can't complain about normal every day noise with that schedule, especially when living by the clubhouse which gets a lot of traffic (near hwy 54, the pool, etc.). Neighbors were at work when I was asleep so the only noise I heard were kids at the pool, lawn keepers, vehicles, etc. With that said, I am used to earplugs and think they are magical. I have been working day shift now for 5 months and I STILL have to wear earplugs. Why??? It's 4 am right now and there is someone banging outside my window. I'm assuming its a maintenance worker at the pool. I know it gets hot during the day but I'm trying to sleep and the earplugs aren't blocking this out!!! This isn't the first time it's happened. I also have to wear earplugs when I wake up at night (to pee) because I can't get back to sleep with all of the birds making noises. That may sound stupid but they are LOUD. It probably has to do with poor insulation which I will get to later. What else is loud besides kids at the pool past midnight, police sirens (every day), maintenance at all hours of the early morning? NEIGHBORS. You can hear everything-people fighting, cooking, music, pets, babies crying etc. that's to be expected though. Pretty sure ours can hear us having a good time. We live on the top floor and still hear people stomping around. When we had our elliptical delivered during the old management's time, we got a noise notice saying our apartment was too loud and "it's probably your elliptical." Well that was impossible because the machine wasn't even set up yet! When I confronted the office about it they said they sent the noise notice to everyone in our building and not to worry because "it's just a warning." This place has had the biggest noise problem of anywhere I've lived. SMELLS-This situation probably has more to do with a combination of my pregnancy and our neighbors. Obviously my sense of smell is extremely sensitive due to the hormones and my husband has always had a strong olfactory sense. With our neighbors being from another country with odiferous food we can smell whenever they are cooking their exotic cuisine. I'm not trying to sound ethnocentric. When it comes to people and their food I do not discriminate trying stuff out- but to constantly smell this stuff is just horrible. And even though its strongest morning, mid-day and evening you cannot get away from it in between. Opening windows helps bring in some fresh air (when the restaurants aren't greasing it up too much next door), but that's impossible to do in the summer and winter. And the smell is so much worse when the heater is on-not sure why exactly? Maybe how the apartments are connected? And air fresher obviously doesn't help. It's unfortunate because the smell was fine before the new neighbors moved in (after we re-signed the lease). I haven't been able to resolve this one and don't think I can without moving. WATER-Whenever it rains there is a huge puddle 3-4 inches of water) at the bottom of the stairs of our building. If it hasn't rained too much we can go around to the adjoining building to the parking lot and not have to soak our feet. If its rained a lot it's MAINTENANCE-We have to call maintenance at least once a month for minor things falling apart (kitchen drawers, door knobs, countertops, molding, etc.) and once to inform them about MOLD growing around the windows (which they told us just to clean with bleach) and is now back. When we first moved here the management told us to call them if we wanted to install ceiling fans. They wanted to be in control of that, which is understandable. We had one at the time and they promptly installed it without any issues. We just got another and called them again and they told us their maintenance guy would do it on his own time for $35. Umm, no thanks. We can do it ourselves. PLUMBING-We hear a loud noise in the pipes when our we use our bathroom or the neighbors flush and I don't mean a normal noise. Sometimes it wakes me up at night it seems to shake the building. I'm sure it does that when we flush too. Toilets also clog VERY easily (hate to say it, but I've never had this issue-not even outside the US). It seems to have something to do with the water pressure. GATE-It works for the most part if you have your key but the other feature has been dysfunctional a lot lately. BOTTOM LINE-Even with all of the issues with different management I feel this place has gone downhill with this new management. I will be looking for a new place today. ***Update***- I spoke with Elliot the manager and they seemed to be on top of some of these things already. I plan to update when I see results. Five stars for approachability and professionalism. I'm hopeful some of these things get done. He actually wrote down some of my complaints.
UPDATE 9/12-Just wanted to say that right after I wrote my last update that we got a severe infestation of ants. It is so frustrating dealing with those, as we had to about the same time last year. It seems they last for about a month and then go away. My husband even found some in his car (usually its just my car that gets them). If management could get this under control this would be an exceptional place to live. **UPDATE 7/1/13** I am updating my review since MANY things have improved since talking to the manager of this place. Scroll down to get a history of the issues- BUGS-As of this year, we have not had any ant infestations in the apartment. After talking to management about the huge ant problem last summer and the infestation in my car, I am optimistic that this summer is different. Things WE have done to prevent ant infestation-no garden on the balcony :( and parking my car in a different area of the complex. While we have seen some ants crawling around there have been so few that we could handle it ourselves. We also had the exterminator come directly to our apartment and spray which has probably helped. Notably, it is a different exterminator than the previous management used and I am happy with the outcome. Kudos to the managers for jumping on the problem when the ants started showing up and not after multiple infestations had already occurred. NOISE-Management definitely fixed the 4 am wake up call done by the guys fixing the pool. It still pisses me off that happened but it's not the complex's fault and it hasn't happened since. Also, there have not been any noisy residents at the pool past 10pm like there were earlier in the summer. The rest of the noise issues still exist but it's an apartment and not that big of a deal IMO. SMELLS-I brought this up to management so they would know if we left (WHICH WE ARE NOT NOW) one of the reasons why. It still sucks living next to these people with their strong ethnic food smell but the good news is they are moving out at the end of this month and I could NOT be happier. Seriously, if we wouldn't have found this out we would have had to move. I just couldn't take the disgusting smell anymore. Now I'm just praying the next neighbors to move in don't stink as well... WATER-THIS HAS BEEN FIXED! UNBELIEVABLE! It poured and flooded yesterday and not a puddle in sight on our property. I honestly can't believe it. Although it was long overdue I am glad this management GOT IT RIGHT. I wouldn't have commented on this unless there was a huge storm and yesterday just proved it to me. Very very good outcome. PLUMBING-This has NOT been addressed since I brought it up to management and it honestly never will. I had my dad (who builds houses) over to even give me an opinion and he said they would have to tear down the wall and fix the pipes (which I know they wouldn't do). It's still annoying but we can live with it. Grrrr. GATE/MAINTENANCE-no changes, but I also didn't bring these up because I thought it would be pointless. PAINT-My husband was thrilled that a few days after my complaints about the other issues management had the black railing painted and it looks amazing. This was something my husband brought up when we first moved here and nothing was done. It does look a lot nicer. It would look even better if the rest of the apartments could be power washed because there's tons of pollen everywhere. They did this at the last place we lived and it looked really nice. But yeah, we are happy about the coat of pain on the railings, it was much needed. POOL-I didn't know this but I guess the pool was busted. That's why I had my 4 am wake up call that one day that pushed me over the edge. Anyway, they got it fixed in 2 days and even had a pool party with all of the residents last Saturday (not that we care, but some people are into that thing). BOTTOM LINE-I have seen some serious improvements in less than a month's time. I am glad about this and it was apparently needed since almost everyone in our building has moved out. Hopefully it will continue to improve and the office's customer service will continue to be outstanding. Like I said below, they have been very approachable and professional through all of this. So even after these issues, we continue to live here because 1) it's a great location and 2) it's a good price for what you get. Rent prices have gone up everywhere and I am surprised to find out what some people pay in this area. I think for the most part, it is reasonable and we plan to stay until the end of our lease. ORIGINAL REVIEW: It's only fair that I admit we have not talked to the New Management about these issues yet. I am going to the office today about it and we'll see how it goes. My husband and I have lived here for 15 months and should have left after our first year but moving is a hassle and we are expecting so we thought it would be easier to stay. It's also a good location for us since my husband loves riding his bike on the trail to downtown Durham and I work in Raleigh. Rent is reasonable but definitely higher than last year and even resident's rates from 2 years ago. And now I am afraid we are going to have to move closer to my due date which is what we were trying to avoid but I can't take it anymore. My husband even agrees and he's not the hormonal one. We have both lived in under developed countries for over 3 years (in older and worse conditions) and have not experienced most ofthese issues, so don't think this is just a first-world problem. BUGS-First summer here we had a huge ant infestation. The company said it was due to the massive amounts of rain we had and that it was only our building. This was a huge issue to resolve and our neighbors had the same experience. Not only was the problem in our house but in our cars as well! I didn't plant a balcony garden this year in hopes to deter inviting anything over. I've already had a huge infestation in my car so I am parking a little farther away from our building and sprayed my car down with ant killer (love the fumes). We have seen some ants in the house exploring but nothing major yet. Also, when we first moved here I saw A roach on 2 occasions but none of those have returned . Which is good because I HATE roaches. I'd argue that it's not a cleanliness issue. It's a property problem. NOISE-When we first moved here I was working night shift so I can't complain about normal every day noise with that schedule, especially when living by the clubhouse which gets a lot of traffic (near hwy 54, the pool, etc.). Neighbors were at work when I was asleep so the only noise I heard were kids at the pool, lawn keepers, vehicles, etc. With that said, I am used to earplugs and think they are magical. I have been working day shift now for 5 months and I STILL have to wear earplugs. Why??? It's 4 am right now and there is someone banging outside my window. I'm assuming its a maintenance worker at the pool. I know it gets hot during the day but I'm trying to sleep and the earplugs aren't blocking this out!!! This isn't the first time it's happened. I also have to wear earplugs when I wake up at night (to pee) because I can't get back to sleep with all of the birds making noises. That may sound stupid but they are LOUD. It probably has to do with poor insulation which I will get to later. What else is loud besides kids at the pool past midnight, police sirens (every day), maintenance at all hours of the early morning? NEIGHBORS. You can hear everything-people fighting, cooking, music, pets, babies crying etc. that's to be expected though. Pretty sure ours can hear us having a good time. We live on the top floor and still hear people stomping around. When we had our elliptical delivered during the old management's time, we got a noise notice saying our apartment was too loud and "it's probably your elliptical." Well that was impossible because the machine wasn't even set up yet! When I confronted the office about it they said they sent the noise notice to everyone in our building and not to worry because "it's just a warning." This place has had the biggest noise problem of anywhere I've lived. SMELLS-This situation probably has more to do with a combination of my pregnancy and our neighbors. Obviously my sense of smell is extremely sensitive due to the hormones and my husband has always had a strong olfactory sense. With our neighbors being from another country with odiferous food we can smell whenever they are cooking their exotic cuisine. I'm not trying to sound ethnocentric. When it comes to people and their food I do not discriminate trying stuff out- but to constantly smell this stuff is just horrible. And even though its strongest morning, mid-day and evening you cannot get away from it in between. Opening windows helps bring in some fresh air (when the restaurants aren't greasing it up too much next door), but that's impossible to do in the summer and winter. And the smell is so much worse when the heater is on-not sure why exactly? Maybe how the apartments are connected? And air fresher obviously doesn't help. It's unfortunate because the smell was fine before the new neighbors moved in (after we re-signed the lease). I haven't been able to resolve this one and don't think I can without moving. WATER-Whenever it rains there is a huge puddle 3-4 inches of water) at the bottom of the stairs of our building. If it hasn't rained too much we can go around to the adjoining building to the parking lot and not have to soak our feet. If its rained a lot it's MAINTENANCE-We have to call maintenance at least once a month for minor things falling apart (kitchen drawers, door knobs, countertops, molding, etc.) and once to inform them about MOLD growing around the windows (which they told us just to clean with bleach) and is now back. When we first moved here the management told us to call them if we wanted to install ceiling fans. They wanted to be in control of that, which is understandable. We had one at the time and they promptly installed it without any issues. We just got another and called them again and they told us their maintenance guy would do it on his own time for $35. Umm, no thanks. We can do it ourselves. PLUMBING-We hear a loud noise in the pipes when our we use our bathroom or the neighbors flush and I don't mean a normal noise. Sometimes it wakes me up at night it seems to shake the building. I'm sure it does that when we flush too. Toilets also clog VERY easily (hate to say it, but I've never had this issue-not even outside the US). It seems to have something to do with the water pressure. GATE-It works for the most part if you have your key but the other feature has been dysfunctional a lot lately. BOTTOM LINE-Even with all of the issues with different management I feel this place has gone downhill with this new management. I will be looking for a new place today. ***Update***- I spoke with Elliot the manager and they seemed to be on top of some of these things already. I plan to update when I see results. Resident
2011 - 2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 12/09/2012
I lived in Southpoint Crossing for about 2 years (different apartments) and I will never move to any of the Bell properties again. The staff is useless and it appeared that maintenance would come in and out of my apartment when I wasn't there. When I terminated my lease I received a notice with one amount that was due at move out. A week later I received the monthly statement that had a different amount so I took both statements to the office. I was told that the statement was incorrect and to pay the amount on the notice. I received a notice one week later that my rent was late and I needed to pay the amount on the statement. When I contacted the office I was told that the notice was sent in error and everything was okay. When I paid the final utilities bill, it included the unpaid balance that I was told was not due. I questioned the balance again and was told that it did not need to be paid and only the utilities was due. After I moved out I received a letter from a collection agency stating that I owed the balance. To avoid ruining my credit I paid the $400.00 balance and contacted the home office about the balance. I have yet to receive a response. These people don't have any clue how to run a business and are just ripping people off. The apartments are overpriced because you don't get any amenities: there's no back splash in the kitchen, the ovens don't have clocks and are not self-cleaning, the lighting is old, countertops are outdated and no crown molding. Other apartments in the area offer more updates and are less expensive. There was always dog feces on the stairs and in the breezeway. I contacted the office about neighbors fighting and yelling in the breezeway and when I was contacted (the next day because there was no courtesy officer), I was told that they would send out a notice to the building. the police were called and I'm sure there was a police report so what was the purpose of sending a notice to everyone in the building! These people only want to collect rent and not do anything else. Parking was horrible, the water pressure in my apartment would drop to a trickle whenever the neighbors used their water. The apartment was not cleaned before I moved in, dog hair everywhere, the painters did a touch-up instead of a full paint job. If you are looking for a great apartment, I would not waste my money at Southpoint Crossing or any of the Bell properties.

Resident
2010 - 2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/21/2011
Out of all the residential communities I have lived in, in the past five years, Southpoint Crossing apartments in Durham is by far the worst apartment complex. In fact, my dorms in college were much more lavished than living in this apartment community. Southpoint Crossing apartment talks a good game to lure you into the community. The apartment staff is consistently changing, and they appear nice, but are extremely worthless. The walls of the apartments are extremely thin. Be prepared to hear everything your neighbor is doing. The walls are so thin you can hear your neighbor blink. And please do not live near stairs. You will hear everything and everyone and never be able to sleep. The community is always filthy yet they have people doing yard work at the crack of dawn waking you up. In fact, when the tornado came in April, some of the sidings on the buildings came off. These same sidings are still loose and can potentially fall on people. There is always broken glass on the grounds because of the wild parties that go on from the college students and many residents do not even pick up after their nasty pets. However, these are not even the worst thing about the community. Southpoint Crossing prides themselves on being a gated community, yet the gate is ALWAYS broken and anyone can easily walk into the neighborhood through the steps. They also have a bad mold problem in their apartments that they are too lazy to treat and tell residents to put bleach and water on it themselves. I have never seen mold this bad before. They use some low budget exterminator, and the company obviously doesn't work because the critters never go away. The office is really slack on maintenance requests, and even when they do come, they don't fix the problems. The parking in the community is the worst! There are so many people who don't live in the community that have their cars parked there for multiple days, yet their cars are never towed. If you want an apartment community who is willing to lie to get your services, and then make you regret your decision, then by all means live in this community. There are so many other great places in Durham, but Southpoint Crossings is NOT one of them

I stayed at Southpoint Crossing from December 2006 to September 2010. I have to say, I obviously enjoyed my stay at the apartment complex. First thing, you cannot control your neighbors or people; no matter where you live. There were a few seasonal car break-ins, but it was happening all around the area. When I first moved there, I did have loud neighbors and they were warned by the staff (no I didn't report them haha). The apartments were in good condition when I moved in. The office staff were ALWAYS friendly to me, even when some issues came up. The maintenance staff were a bunch of awesome guys that I would take care of any of my issues in a timely manner. They were also great guys to talk to when you saw them around. The only major issues I had with the complex was when the water was turned off at the car washing section at times where it wasn't needed. I dreaded washing my clothes at the community washer and dryers. They were outdated and I have lost plenty of change in those machines. I always treated the staff how I wanted to be treated, and they returned the favor.

I am in the process of moving to the area. No, I'm not apart of the management here, because I know many of you who want to complain think that if its not negative then it must be an employess. Well it's not. I just laugh at your reviews. Have you never lived at an apartment community before this? You are renting, which if you want things your way... BUY! You people are not the only tenants who live there. I worked part time while in school at a community and let me tell you, there is never a slow moment. There isn't time to personally come "knock" on your door to discuss why you apparently can't abide by the community polocies. Communities don't take cash because of your own safety. It's not just here, its everywhere! Maybe a shady property would, but this polocy protects you so don't complain. Pay your rent on time and its not an issue... you don't have to worry about late rent procedures. Those who want to complain about apartment noise.... IT'S AN APARTMENT! Management can not tell someone to not walk around. If its music or something that can be controlled, I'm sure that a letter would be sent out. If it bothers you that much, get off your lazy --- and go tell them to cut it down yourself because sometimes people don't pay attention to what management says. Or better yet BUY a house! People you kill me with your complaints. I've lived in a one bedroom that cost over $800 a month and still had the noise issue. Its a part of living in an apartment... sad, but true. Those who are looking for a place, keep in mind that residents who come to these sites have most likely not gotten their way so this is a way to get revenge on a community. Luckily, I've been in the business before so I know a little bit about it to not listen to some of it. Granted some of the reviews, like the drugs and type of people living their throw up a red flag but look at dates too. Find out if its under new management and see if problems have been resolved. Also keep in mind, income for a person wanting to move in is based on an rent to income ratio.... the cheaper the rent the lower class people to live there because they don't need to make a lot to qualify. Lastly, this is Durham and Southpoint mall is right down the street from the ghetto/hood. So don't leave things that are costly in ur car. You will get targeted, its not rocket science people. Use your own judgement and keep "real life" scenerios in mind when reading any rating. Some of these people just have no common sense apparently because some of their complaints show their character and you can see why there may have been problems.

2008 - 2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/26/2009
i lived at southpoint crossing for 1 year and never had any complaints. my apartment had a great view of the pool and was close to the fitness center and shopping center next door. i was able to catch the bus in front of the community when i needed to go somewhere. i liked that it had gates to go through and that i had to buzz my friends in. i didn't have a car, but there was plenty of parking for my guests. the office staff always helped me out with the computer lab, and they were always friendly to me. i would recommend this community to anyone looking for a very convienent place to live and wants stuff to do around them (southpoint mall).

Resident
2006 - 2007 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/06/2007
This complex is not all that old. On the surface, it looks well-built. When you go to open the blinds in the master bedroom, you find one of the windows is completely steamed with humidity, even on a hot dry day. "Oh, they're all like that" explains the maintenance man, who refuses to replace the window. Then you go to open the dishwasher door and the whole dishwasher falls three inches on one side due to rot in the countertop where it mounts. Repair is done with glue. Drops again 2 days later. The view from the deck must be great, no? Yeah it's great if you like watching the thugs coming down from the shopping center to buy their drugs in the apartment building next door. They're not in the least bit low-key about it, alerting all to their presence with the thumpity-thump-thump-thump of their obnoxious subwoofers. This goes on at ALL hours of the night. The walls are thin. Unless you are on the third floor, you will hear EVERYTHING going on above you. The walking, the TV set, even the sex lives of the people who live above you. In great detail. Keep in mind I am hearing impaired, 50dB of loss in each ear, and I knew all the sordid details of what the college girls upstairs were into due to the poor sound proofing. The parking lot is very dangerous. People drive through at incredible speeds, cutting corners and ending up on the wrong side of the road. Lots of thugs with their racing motorcycles burning out in the parking lot, or running glasspack mufflers on their cars and making a point of letting everyone know about it. Big dogs are permitted. The lady downstairs had 4 or 5 dogs and would often let them go without a leash. Staff didn't car. Dog poop is everywhere. When you drive by in the golf cart the grass looks nice but heaven forbid you try walking in it. There is a car wash facility but good luck getting into it. Much of the time there is a full size conversion van in there. After he's done washing it, he polishes & waxes it INSIDE the car wash booth. No consideration for others. I never did get a chance to use it myself. There is trash and discarded food all over the place, in the hallways, etc. I expect rats to infest the place soon if they haven't already. The pool is usually occupied by people who don't even live at Southpoint Crossing. They bring liquor, and several times a year the pool is closed and drained to removed glass from broken beer and liquor bottles. The people who occupy the pool are very territorial and harrass the actual residents who try to use the pool. The apartment staff refuses to hire a lifeguard to check tags to make sure only residents are using the pool facilities. They lure you in with cheap rent and then right before your lease is due for renewal they drop the bomb on you with a huge rent increase. The 5-star ratings you see here are fake, perpetrated by the apartment management to try and lure you in. Don't fall for it. This place is a dump. There was a rapist running around at one point. Cars are being stolen. Apartments are being broken into. I can't tell you how many times the maintenance crew "accidentally" tried letting themselves into my apartment! They just let themselves in without any appointment or anything, with no concern for your safety or privacy. The office staff appears friendly on the surface but they often misplace paperwork, always to your detriment. Office staff organization is very poor. They often make promises and conveniently "forget". Basically they tried getting some attractive looking people that could "sell" leases but once you're in it all changes. Rent jumped over $150 when the lease renewed!

The truth shale set you freeee.............................. bunch of *thugs* who are attracted by the cheap rent and then move out within a year. The neighborhood is rapidly turning into a bunch of gangstas driving around with their subwoofers cranked up, doing smokey burnouts in the parking lot, and seeing how fast they can drive through. I had the distinct pleasure of living downstairs from some thugs. The subwoofers turn on at about 11pm and don't stop until 3am or later. The apartment management is unwilling to do anything about it. The Durham cops aren't too motivated, either. Tenants throw trash on the ground, and the maintenance crew leaves it there. Landscaping is done regularly but it is by unskilled illegal immigrants who overlook a lot of things because they don't care (and aren't paid to care) enough to do a better job. More than one time I've had the maintenance crew let themselves into my apartment with NO emergency, NO appointment, a knock and a ten second wait. Completely inexcusable! Oh and whenever the summer storms would come in with strong winds and rain, my bedroom window would pop out of its tracks into the room and water would be everywhere. Maintenance crew would do nothing about this. Similarly the master bedrooms all have this one window that won't open and is fogged up 95% of the time. All of the units have this problem so that window is a complete waste. The drug problem has gotten particularly bad in the last year. Buyers & sellers park up at the top of the stairs at all hours of the night behind the Kroger and run down, buy their drugs, linger in the parking lot awhile, and move on out. Lots of shady characters hanging around. The office staff appeared friendly but some of them were pretty apathetic (some were effective though). I would hand them important signed paperwork that needed to be processed and it would just get lost. This happened several times. I do have to thank them for one thing: by jacking my rent up they proved to me that I could afford to buy a house in North Raleigh. Life has been so much sweeter since I've moved out of Southpoint Crossing.

2004 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/10/2006
I am male, lived here 2 years in 2 bdrm apartment. We were living here while we repaired and sold our house and decided to stay another year. It's very convenient to shopping & health services and economical...probably too economical. It takes a lot of diligence to fill a medium rent complex and not invite trouble. Unfortunately, in the past year there has been little diligence and more trouble. This past year has seen repeated break ins and auto thefts (office suggested was a resident), a reported rape, wandering 'free booters' (don't live here) taking over the pool breaking whiskey bottles there (despite it being next to the office), roaring Harley bikes at all hours, trash in the hall ways and on porches (soon the rats), beer cans and bottle in the hall ways. The last time that I saw this type of negligence was with absentee land lords in New York. Regretfully, the proprietor, Stephen Bell Proterties, is just about that. Too bad. There goes millions of dollars down the drain. There are better places near by where I shall be soon.<br><br>Update: I changed my rating to "conditional" recommend. If you cannot pay higher rent, this place is now, as in Lake Woebegone, "above average"...considering. The management did respond to a degree to complaints about the pool, some of the noisier residents and has a plan/procedure about security although I don't know if it will work since it's not agressive and not well known. At least three police officers live here, sleep here anyway. It's something but it may not do much good (briefly, I was a police officer. Policing gets done where you put in awake time, not sleeping time). Maint staff is good, office staff pretty good...but they don't live here (used to be one but no more). Regretfully, we now also see signs of "light" drug activity partly spilling over from that 'convenient' shopping plaza. It's still very convenient and I shall be soon missing that. The other 'old people' are staying but staying indoors at night they say. (There IS that economy convenience) We decided to remain renters but higher rent for the same space really is required to flush out problem tenants. So we stepped up 50% (checked ratings here first) and visited the new complex at all hours before we signed. It also helps if the rules require each unrelated adult renter have qualifying income. Some apartments with higher rent do not so you get three families in a three bedroom unit. No good. For 100% increase, there are some very nice units in Chapel Hill. This has been quite an education. These places are not easy to run for a profit.
I am male, lived here 2 years in 2 bdrm apartment. We were living here while we repaired and sold our house and decided to stay another year. It's very convenient to shopping & health services and economical...probably too economical. It takes a lot of diligence to fill a medium rent complex and not invite trouble. Unfortunately, in the past year there has been little diligence and more trouble. This past year has seen repeated break ins and auto thefts (office suggested was a resident), a reported rape, wandering 'free booters' (don't live here) taking over the pool breaking whiskey bottles there (despite it being next to the office), roaring Harley bikes at all hours, trash in the hall ways and on porches (soon the rats), beer cans and bottle in the hall ways. The last time that I saw this type of negligence was with absentee land lords in New York. Regretfully, the proprietor, Stephen Bell Proterties, is just about that. Too bad. There goes millions of dollars down the drain. There are better places near by where I shall be soon.<br><br>Update: I changed my rating to "conditional" recommend. If you cannot pay higher rent, this place is now, as in Lake Woebegone, "above average"...considering. The management did respond to a degree to complaints about the pool, some of the noisier residents and has a plan/procedure about security although I don't know if it will work since it's not agressive and not well known. At least three police officers live here, sleep here anyway. It's something but it may not do much good (briefly, I was a police officer. Policing gets done where you put in awake time, not sleeping time). Maint staff is good, office staff pretty good...but they don't live here (used to be one but no more). Regretfully, we now also see signs of "light" drug activity partly spilling over from that 'convenient' shopping plaza. It's still very convenient and I shall be soon missing that. The other 'old people' are staying but staying indoors at night they say. (There IS that economy convenience) We decided to remain renters but higher rent for the same space really is required to flush out problem tenants. So we stepped up 50% (checked ratings here first) and visited the new complex at all hours before we signed. It also helps if the rules require each unrelated adult renter have qualifying income. Some apartments with higher rent do not so you get three families in a three bedroom unit. No good. For 100% increase, there are some very nice units in Chapel Hill. This has been quite an education. These places are not easy to run for a profit. Read less

2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/20/2004
I lived at Southpoint Crossing from March to September 2004. I found it to be a very nice place to live, in a great location, for a reasonable rent. I moved out this September because I had finally saved enough to put a down payment on a home.<br><br>I was very pleased with the layout and square footage of my 1 BR apt, especially for the price. I rented a washer and dryer, so I can't speak to the laundry facilities, but the pool is nice and often used. The location is fantastic. It is super convenient to RTP and the Streets at Southpoint, and you can walk to the supermarket and numerous restaurants. Also, the community is bordered by an city-sponsored trail ("rails to trails") that is great for biking, walking, or running. All in all, I was very pleased with the apartment I lived in and the service I received from the friendly staff.<br><br>Note: The move-out process is a cinch if you clean your apartment. I had no problems or complaints.<br>

I have found none of these to be true. I have had a great experience here. My neighbors are great, there is an abundance of parking spaces even when the building is fully occupied, and maintenance is only a phone call away. The staff have been excellent, specifically Amy Leber, whos name has been wrongfully smeared throughout these reviews by the cowardly tennants who will not simply talk to her, is a great manager. During my time here I lost my job. Amy was a a blessing during a stressfull time. Not only did I lose my job but I feared I could lose my home too. Amy told me not to worry and we worked everything out. Recently my lease was not renewed here. Amy immediatly offered to help me find a new place. She is not the eveil tyrant that people make her out to be. If you are upfront and honest with her, she will go out of her way for you. Some people will find something wrong where ever they go, so keep that in mind and give Southpoint Crossings a chance! Read less

Resident
2000 - 2004 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/21/2004
We have lived here at Southpoint Crossing, originally Archstone, for nearly three years now. In that time, management has changed, and several of the conditions have declined significantly. <br><br>First, to discuss the choosy enforcement of lease terms. It is stated in the lease that "any pet MUST be removed from the premises if lessor's sole discression it is determined constitutes a nuisance or creates a disturbance or poses a threat to the safety of any person or property." Recently there was a dog biting incident where a current resident's dog bit a neighbor. The dog according to state law was quarantined for two weeks, however, months later is still on the premises. In a separate incident, a resident's dog was allowed to reside at Southpoint Crossing, with full understanding of the dog's breed -a Staffordshire Terrier. The office staff determined just one year later that the dog resembled an aggessive breed and refused to renew the tenant's lease (although the dog has never showed agression upon any resident or caused disturbance.) If you would ask any neighbor or the younger maintenance man (who did have an agressive breed mix on the premises prior) they would all agree that these dogs are not a threat. Also, a resident who recently acquired a purebread German Rottweiler was told by a member of the office staff that if any one asked what kind of dog it was, to tell them it is "a mixed breed." There are currently 2 Rottweiler's, an Akita, and several Pitt Bull's living here under the current management. If these dogs are all on the "agressive breed list," and they are still residing here, they why are others of questionable breed getting the boot. <br><br>Second, is the issue of pool hours. It is stated in the North Carolina Lease that pool hours are from 8:30am to 10:00pm. However, nowhere on the premises are pool hours posted. They have to post lifeguard and pet signs, then why not post hours (if they are going to be enfoced by law officials, who also took notice that they were nowhere to be posted.)<br><br>Third, to discuss the issue of unnessary apartment entry. Normally when the office staff has either newsletters or notices, they are tucked inside of the resident's main door. When the office notified me to let me know that I had a notice, I told them I would not be home and the time, but to leave it on the door as usual. When I returned home, however, the notice that was suppose to be left in the door, was sitting on my kitchen counter. Why??? I know that they have a right to enter the premises, but was this necessary?<br><br>Forth, the issue of the efficiency of maintenance requests. There have been several problems surrounding the issues of mold, mice, termites, spiders, and other unidentified critters. Forget about anything being taken care of promptly. If you have a maintenance emergency (such as maggots on your pantry ceiling, mice or spiders), hold tight, because the Orkin man is only contracted on Thursday's. You will more than likely have to wait till the following week to have those problems resolved. <br><br>Fifth, the VEHICULAR DETERRANTS (aka. entry gates). Within the last year, the gates have maybe worked for a period of about two weeks straight, and then they are once again broken. This place is definitely not concerned about the quality of life, and you pay way too much for what you get (not to mention, having the gates hanging there all of the time looks somewhat ghetto.)<br><br>Lastly, if the community deems it necessary to not renew your lease, don't expect a reason, because apparently they do not have to give you one (as I was so promptly told). Huh...Promptly...Southpoint Crossing...Definitely two words that shouldn't be used together. <br><br>~Written in conjunction by several current<br> unsatisfied Southpoint Crossing residents.<br> <br><br> <br><br>

Resident
2001 - 2004 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/28/2004
I must concur with those who found Southpoint Crossing Apartments lacking in quality service and environs. I have recently moved out of state but lived there for three years. In that time I suffered through a snow storm in which my power was disconnected for 10 days. Not only did I have to find a hotel to stay at, but Southpoint Crossing refused to lower my rent for the month in which my apartment was unliveable. <br> <br>I also had serious mold problems around the windows of the main bedroom of the apartment that went ignored for years. I eventually had to devise a scheme to prevent moisture from building up on the windows which helped only marginally. The windows were always sweating and letting moisture in. After reporting this several times to the staff and having "repair" men come by to look at it, all they could do was throw their hands up. They did absolutely nothing to fix the problem. <br> <br>Finally, the staff is quite rude. I was threatened with a lawsuit for simply disputing with Amy Leber the finer points of landlord tenant law in North Carolina (I just graduated from law school). I simply tried to correct a mistatement of the law she made and she promptly threatened to sue me. On top of that, when I was having my move-out inspection my mother who is 66 years old came with me to help me pack and clean. I was originally told that I and the inspector would walk or ride the cart together to my apartment to look it over. Amy Leber looked at me and my mother who was somewhat winded from the original walk and forced us to walk back to the apartment while she rode in her golf cart. I have reported this conduct to the better business bureau and think it is unconscionable. Perhaps others have had a better experience, but I did not. I was a good tenant who never caused any problems and was treated with a good measure of disrespect.

Resident
2002 - 2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/06/2004
I don't know why everyone else is complaining about this apartment complex. My wife and I feel very fortunate to have found an apartment this nice for what we are paying. As for a previously posted opinion, there is no way that the Lodge at Southpoint is cheaper than Southpoint Crossing. The trail here is great for jogging, biking, and walking your dog. My wife has never felt unsafe here. We have never had any problems with the management and the maintenance staff has always been very prompt. We have not seen a single insect inside our apartment and there is no mold on our windows. The gate is not for security; they tell you that when you move in. It is mainly for traffic control. It is true that it is broken a lot, but that just means you don't have to stop on your way in. We would definitely recommend these apartments.

I currently live at Southpoint Crossing, and I am moving out next month. As you have read from other reviewers, this is not a good place to live. This complex has continued to decline since Archstone sold the property to SD Bell and Company. The staff are the rudest people I have ever met. Currently the manager is Amy Leber, and any resident will agree that she is one of the most rudest people you will ever meet. 2002 - 2003 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/18/2003
I have been living here for a little over a year. The community has always been nice in my opinion. There are good floor plans to choose from, with great kitchens and huge pantries--I love to cook and entertain. <br> <br>Lately, they have been working on adding on to the community. They are expanding the fitness center (which I need to utilize more often), adding a business center, building more garages/storage units for rent, and doing some changes in the office. It´s a little bit of a mess right now, but it will be worth it once the work is complete. I´m not looking foward to seeing what my rent is going to be though, the new management company´s prices seem to be a little steeper than before. <br> <br>Overall, this seems to be a pretty safe place. I´ll admit, I have heard of one or two car break-ins, one of which I actually saw the car that got targeted...it lost its rims and tires--hate that for the owner, but living in an apartment community doesn´t exactly ensure that things like this won´t happen from time-to-time. My goodness people, this is 2003! In my opinion, crime cannot all out be avoided, it´s everywhere in this world! But again, I think that because this community is in such a populated area, its safety ranks higher than others. I just don´t think that people can base everything solely off of this, it cannot be avoided and isn´t anyone´s fault. s#!* happens, right? (excuse the language, I used this only to make a point) <br> <br>I do wish we had a tennis court or volleyball court or something. There is the gym and pool, but that´s it. I would rather play tennis or bump around a volleyball than be caught dead in skimpy clothes working out or trying to swim off the results of my culinary hobbies. Just an opinion. <br> <br>My neighbors are pretty nice, I always try to be friendly and haven´t experienced anyone too terribly awful yet. <br> <br>The grounds need a little work, especially around the lake area. I live in an apartment facing the lake. I think it adds to the perks, but the lake is such a mess. I always see trash around the sides of it. And my neighbors are often a little lazy about sometimes cleaning up after their little fidos...There are pet waste things all around the community, so that shouldn´t be as big as a problem as it sometimes is, but heck, the grass seems to grow greener because of it! <br> <br>And last thing...location is great. Anything and everything I want or need is so close! The area is growing a lot, so we may need to be a little more cautious since it could bring in some trouble-makers, but I´m remaining positive.
I have been living here for a little over a year. The community has always been nice in my opinion. There are good floor plans to choose from, with great kitchens and huge pantries--I love to cook and entertain. <br> <br>Lately, they have been working on adding on to the community. They are expanding the fitness center (which I need to utilize more often), adding a business center, building more garages/storage units for rent, and doing some changes in the office. It´s a little bit of a mess right now, but it will be worth it once the work is complete. I´m not looking foward to seeing what my rent is going to be though, the new management company´s prices seem to be a little steeper than before. <br> <br>Overall, this seems to be a pretty safe place. I´ll admit, I have heard of one or two car break-ins, one of which I actually saw the car that got targeted...it lost its rims and tires--hate that for the owner, but living in an apartment community doesn´t exactly ensure that things like this won´t happen from time-to-time. My goodness people, this is 2003! In my opinion, crime cannot all out be avoided, it´s everywhere in this world! But again, I think that because this community is in such a populated area, its safety ranks higher than others. 2002 - 2003 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/23/2003
There are so many things I could write about Archstone Southpoint, but I´ll keep it simple. It all begins when you move in. The management staff are all friendly people and they seem like they genuinely care until something happens to you. Then, they are like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. Their true side comes out. In fact, they are rude and very unprofessional. They proved that they definitely don´t care about the well being of their residents. There have been NUMEROUS CAR AND APT BREAK-INS. Why wouldn´t it be though? The gates are always wide open for anyone that wants to enter. You definitely don´t need a gate card. Anyway, Archstone isn´t a truly gated community. You can walk straight to the shopping center without going outside of the gate. <br>You can complain all you want to about the apartment after you´ve signed your lease, but they don´t care. They only want to put on a fake smile for prospects until they´ve agreed to move in and collect your rent. DO NOT FALL FOR THEIR LITTLE SCAM!!!!! <br>The bottom line is that Archstone isn´t safe for anyone. A place like that DESPERATELY needs an onsite police officer and alarm systems in EVERY apartment. If you truly care about your well being, Archstone Southpoint should be one of your last resorts. DO NOT MOVE HERE! To the management: GET RID OF THE "100% SATISFACTION GUARANTEED"...it´s false advertising!
